title: Resources
text:
Below is a curated list of spatial data, and conservaiton related resources for Vancouver, southern British Columbia, and beyond. This page is intended to be a living document, growing with our community.
If you have a useful GIS/conservation resource you don’t see listed, please let us know

title: Resources
text:
Data Portals
These are primary, large-scale open data portals for municipal, regional, provincial, and federal GIS data.

City of Vancouver Open Data Portal

The city’s portal for high-resolution municipal data, including urban ecology, green spaces, street trees, and utilities.

Metro Vancouver Open Data Portal

Provides regional-scale data that cross municipal boundaries in the lower mainland, such as regional parks, land use, and remote sensing data.

BC Data Catalogue

Contains datasets from B.C. government ministries, including wildlife, forestry, water, administrative boundaries, and base maps.

Government of Canada Open Data Portal

The federal portal for national-scale datasets. This portal contains data related to tidal fisheries (DFO), national parks (Parks Canada), federal species at risk (SARA), and climate (Environment and Climate Change Canada).

title: Resources
text:
Conservation & Environmental Data Hubs
These resources are more specialized, focusing specifically on biodiversity, ecosystems, and natural resource management in British Columbia.

BC Conservation Data Centre (CDC)

Information on species and ecosystems at risk in B.C.

iMapBC

An interactive web-mapping application from the B.C. government that provides access to hundreds of integrated datasets.

Community Mapping Network (CMN)

A network that supports community-based mapping and data collection.

Welcome to the homepage for the newly formed (est. November 2025) Vancouver, BC Chapter of the Society for Conservation GIS.
This group aims to bring together the community of conservation related Geographic Information System (GIS) related individuals across Vancouver and the greater region of southern British Columbia.
Our chapter is an affiliated chapter of the Society for Conservation GIS (SCGIS).
The SCGIS helps bring together conservation practitioners and GIS technology by supporting communication and networking, scholarships, and training across the world through a system of connected chapters in various cities and countires. Membership is open to anyone looking to engage in a GIS conservation related community.
